Walking Rate Experiment

Make a Prediction:

  • What is the ratio of rise to run in the set of stairs?

Equipment:

  • Access to various sets of stairs to measure
  • Measuring device, such as, tape measure or ruler
  • Paper and pencil or other materials to record your results, such as Learning Aid 4.1

Directions (with a partner or group):

  • Measure the rise and run for a few stairs
  • Record the ratios of the rise to the run
  • Repeat for a new set of stairs

Analyze the Data:

  • Is the steepness the same between any two consecutive steps?

Students answer will vary.

Many stairs do have consistent rise and run measurements. In some unusual cases, the rise and run may vary on a set of stairs. It is an interesting conversation to discuss how this can impact walking on the stairs and how safe or steady people feel on them.
• What is the relationship between the rise and run for stairs that seem steep? How does it compare to your prediction?

Student answers will vary.

Interesting situations to think about include: spiral staircases, school stairs, large steps (like at a museum), etc.
• How do the stairs you measured compare to the carpenters' guidelines?

Students answers will vary.

Example: 7.25 in. to 11.25 inches for the rise to the run, or approximately 0.70 for the ratio of rise to run. This is the same for every step in the staircase. The ratio of rise to run is not within the carpenterâ€™s guidelines.
